datasets.label: PL-REX_1k
datasets.title: PL-REX_1k Protein-ligand complexes with reliable affinities.
datasets.chartTitle: Error of tested methods in the PL-REX_1k data set
description: This website collects the results of approximate computational chemistry methods and machine learning potentials computed in the PL-REX_1k benchmark data set.
The PL-REX_1k data set contains 10 noncovalent complexes (~1000 atoms) each with a series of ligands (164 in total).

The error of the tested method is expressed as a mean unsigned error and listed in kcal/mol or in percent relative to the average magnitude of the reference interaction energy in the set. The methods are divided into three categories: semiempirical quantum-mechanical calculations (SQM), atomistic machine learning potentials (ML), and the hybrid methods combining both approaches (SQM+ML).
More results can be added via the GitHub repository

datasets.label: PLA15
datasets.title: PLA15 Protein-ligand interaction energy benchmarks
datasets.chartTitle: Error of tested methods in the PLA15 data set
description: This website collects the results of approximate computational chemistry methods and machine learning potentials computed in the PLA15 benchmark data set.

The PLA15 dataset features 15 models of protein-ligand complexes covering the interaction of the ligand with nearby amino acid residues. The systems range in size from 280 to 580 atoms. Reference interaction energies were obtained from fragment-based DLPNO-CCSD(T) calculations and represent the most accurate benchmark available for biomolecular systems of this size.

The error of the tested method is expressed as a mean unsigned error and listed in kcal/mol or in percent relative to the average magnitude of the reference interaction energy in the set. The methods are divided into three categories: semiempirical quantum-mechanical calculations (SQM), atomistic machine learning potentials (ML), and the hybrid methods combining both approaches (SQM+ML).
More results can be added via the GitHub repository, which also provides the PLA15 structures and a sample code performing the calculations on them. Contributions of new data are welcome!

datasets.label: S66
datasets.title: S66 interaction energies in organic noncovalent complexes
datasets.chartTitle: Error of tested methods in the S66 data set
description: This website collects the results of approximate computational chemistry methods and machine learning potentials computed in the S66 benchmark data set.

The S66 data set contains 66 noncovalent complexes of organic molecules representing typical interactions in biomolecules, including hydrogen bonding, dispersion, and mixed interactions. The reference interaction energies were computed at the CCSD(T)/CBS level of theory.

The error of the tested method is expressed as a mean unsigned error and listed in kcal/mol or in percent relative to the average magnitude of the reference interaction energy in the set. The methods are divided into three categories: semiempirical quantum-mechanical calculations (SQM), atomistic machine learning potentials (ML), and the hybrid methods combining both approaches (SQM+ML).
More results can be added via the GitHub repository
